title: E3D Fan Duct with DC42 Differential IR Sensor Mount (E3D Titan Version Available)

description.text:
This is a pressure-mounted fan and differential IR sensor mount for the E3D V6 extruder.

This is a combination of two excellent things, the E3D V6 fan shroud, and simon0362's slimline sensor mount that usually goes between the fan and the fan shroud.

Simply screw the sensor board onto the mount, capacitor facing forward, and then screw the fan in. The mount clips to the heat sink exactly like the official one. Recalibrate your printer's M851 offset, and you're good to go.

Creation pipeline: Slic3r for mashing up and slicing, pronsole to feed gcode, and a lovely wreck of a reprap printer.

UPDATE: Added a version designed to bolt onto an E3D Titan above, for added vertical and rotational stability. Bumping or messing with the extruder with the simpler version can knock your offset out of what, requiring recalibrating the distance between nozzle and bed when at Z=0. This helps alleviate that by using the extruder body to keep the entire assembly at a constant distance.

The added flange is a bit ugly, but sits level on the E3D Titan faceplate.

author: sybu

description.text:
Hey guys.

If you're a FDM 3D printer user, you will offen find tolerance between printed real things & original design, which is really annoying especially adapted to screws or other things.

Maybe only solution is to print a series of shapes with adjacent size to calibrate.

Here I present a tool to make this process easier.

With the cutomerized Scad files, you just tell him:

  • You want generate suqares or circles(2 shapes most used)
  • Size range(Which size & differeces between each shape)
  • How many shapes to generate.

Then it will generate a series of shapes for you, print it and compare it with real things, then you know the right size for your design!!

Have fun and hope it may help!

print_settings.Notes:: These settings don't really matter, really. I used white PLA though

description.text:
This piece is to be glued on the bottom of a glass microwave oven plate that doesn't have the little knobs to rotate the plate
(remember, a microwave oven that doesn't rotate isn't a real microwave oven, as once said Thorin Oakenshield)
This is in case you found a compatible plate (pawn shop or else) that doesn't have the knobs underneath. You can glue this on the underside. Use microwave-safe epoxy, not CA glue/super glue.
Edit : One of these was installed in my microwave oven and melted after I made some microwave popcorn... You might have to consider this, or printing a bunch, replacing them after a while...
An article on the making of this piece can be found on my website

author: Ph4n70M

description.text:
Designed as an RxClip replacement for the Shimano range of cycling glasses: I found the retail RxClip had an unusable and unsafe distortion amount with moderate to high nearsighted prescriptions due to the lenses curving around with the main lenses -  this design flattens the lenses and gives me pretty much perfect vision using the same lenses I had made for the RxClip (I'm -6 in both eyes as a point of reference).   
Just to avoid any confusion - it's just the insert not the glasses frame too - ie the separate black item on the plate in the photo. The white print installed in the glasses is t-glase which seems a pretty ideal material for this item.  
It is designed to be mounted using the metal bracket that comes with the glasses and previously held the rubber nose piece - gives a very solid install.

Printed at 0.1mm, probably OK at higher settings.   
Turn on Supports but Raft is optional (I had no issues printing without raft).   
You may need to adjust the nose pads in your favourite modelling app for that custom fit, stick on rubber pads are probably an option too.  
Works well in PLA or t-glase, I assume ABS would be fine too - the nylon I tried wasn't rigid enough.  
I used some small rubber o-rings to hold the frames closed, though you could probably print a small clip.  
Use the metal bracket that comes with the glasses themselves (assuming they are the same across the range as the Equinox I have)  to mount this bracket to the frames, it gives a very solid fit - the print has grooves designed for the metal arms.

comments.text: An alternative is to adjust the prescription to account for the lens wrap. This should help: http://opticampus.com/tools/tilt.phphttp://opticampus.com/tools/ti....

description.text:
I made this pot to plant seeds one by one. Using it for dates currently. Their roots get deep so that is the reason for the shape. Would be good to have it in customizer scad format... one day i will learn that :)
One pot is about 23g and prints under one hour.

Update 2017.06.30:
Summer is here and pots are outside. They get direct sunlight for a few hours every day. Some of them melted a little :) but still holding up. Impressive from PLA.

Update 2016.10.24:
Added a little chamfer to the bottom so if you have leftover from brim or not-so-good looking first layers it will not prevent stacking. Tolerance is 0.2mm ad it works OK for me.
I made 6 pcs and it fits thigh when multiple pots are sliding at once.
Might be good to add +0.1mm to fit more easily.

Update 2017.02.13:
Dont be afraid of PLA composting too fast! Over 3 months now and single walled pots are still holding up. See last photo (With LED lamp :) )

This derivative of the original Gothic Cathedral Play Set has been cleaned up and tested with the current generation of slicing tools. Skinforge was primitive and slow, but it would slice anything eventually. MakerWare and Slic3r are much more efficient, but can't readily cope with the geometric errors present in many older models The clean-up was done using Netfabb Basic.and the SketchUp plug-ins SolidInspector and CleanUp. Solid Inspector is available for download here: http://extensions.sketchup.com/en/content/solid-inspector CleanUp is available for download here:
http://extensions.sketchup.com/en/content/cleanup%C2%B3

Lets not fool ourselves, these things are evil even without glowing red eyes and horrid scowling grimaces full of wide teeth.
  • Agh, looks like the date info is based on Thingiverse's location. Wile it was March 2nd at the Thingiverse server home it was still march 1st on another half of the planet when I posted this. Hopefully this is still within the contest limitations.

I highly recommend the fluorescent green and red/orange for this guy. Though seeing him in glow in the dark abs might be kinda cool. 
Some of the areas are going to need support, so its safe to just start off with that from the get-go. Hes pretty tall so you better have some good settings to mash those layers together. The main pictures show straight thorns, but there's also some curved ones I put on the plate with the eyes. 
Have at it folks, and let me know how you like it!

Marvels Doctor strange magic attack,

it is made for the costum challange, i used reference out off the new comming movie (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lt-U_t2pUHI) and out of the comics and merchandise.
for some of the magic runes i even used games to get a most realistic prop.

i used the makerbot replicator 5th gen with 2 special pla filaments neutral color to get a semi transparancy for the bottom plate and transparant orange to get the color effect on the runes. but with the neutral color i was getting printer error and had to print again and again with no succes of yet. but with the full transparant orange filament i got a succesfull print. im now trying to print it again but am using basic white fillamant as the bottom part of the print. i will add the photo of it later if it is a succes.

it was a little thinking on how i would make it possible to hold. so i design a brace on the back so it will stay on your hand when wearing it.

hope you like it and if you make it yourself would love to see photo's.

The design was made in adobe illustrator and saved als a SVG, had to resave the svg using inkscape because i had a problem loading the svg in fusion 360 was getting errors.

there are 395 sections in the design and after extruding every one of them en checking if everything was correct i made a circel to place everything on it and finish the design.

title: Customiser: Storage container for ball bearings

description.text:
Reduces pressure on drawer box use, freeing boxes by means of storing different size ball bearings in a single compartment without forfeiting organisation.
This amazing feat is made possible by storing each type of ball bearing in its own cylindric container, which are churned out by your 3D-printer. They feature a more or less tightly fitting lid, as preventive against unauthorized exit from ball bearing storage.
Customiser provides a facility to impress or emboss the ball bearing type information into or onto cylinder wall, read from the respective size and type specification record. but print quality of such labeling hasn't been great as far, therefore I reverted to more traditional pen-on-cardboard-with-sticky-tape labeling method, which works for now.

Several things still need to be done:

  • impressed/embossed text doesn't show in customiser preview
  • parametric selection by sliders not done
  • alternative bearings selection by pulldown not done
  • cap (lid) doesn't show in customiser preview.
    ** reducing variable fit to 0, then increasing again to original or alternative value seems to remedy this

It seems that at the moment, downloading and editing the according values yourself is a better options than letting customiser generate an .stl for download. I hope that I can eventually fix those issues.

A set of 4 concentric rings with handles that can each be snapped into each other in 8 different positions. This was an experimental toy to see how spinning the outer ring affected the inner ones when they are set to different positions. title: Double mounting carriage delta 2020
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This carriage is a remix from a parts file which was provided by my first (chinese) delta. Therefore i can't give the right person the appropriated credits, sorry.

I used the dimensions of the original to redraw the carriage using Sketch up.
This carriage has 5 wheels instead off the original 3. The reason is to get more stability of the carriage during printing. The extra mountings are created to fit eventually a airstruder.
(airstruder not yet ready).
The carriage has an opening to fit a 3mm nut. This gives the endstop adjuster more reliability, than just 3mm threads tapped into the carriage.
The tensioner for the wheel is a trough and trough hole. with at the other side room for a 3mm nut. Also to ensure better fixture, and the nut is now easier to place than the original design.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

the stiffer the better

Notes:

I printed this carriage with PLA.
ABS may be preferred to PLA.

I used rollers which i bought at our local superstore (22 diameter, the are not v shaped.) These are normally used for gliding doors.
The size of the wheels can make a difference in how the carriage and his rods are aligned.
For my printer i had to create an offset to get the rods properly aligned. And evenly spaced to the 2020 bar.

2 m3 nutt's are creating the appropriate alignment

I was looking for an airstuder. Because i want to start printing/experimenting with flexible filament.
But do the fact that my current printer has an large size (110 cm high and 35 round printbed). The bowden fixture has also an large tube. Normally gives this enlargement no problems. However some printing files give me issues with the filament retraction settings. And also for flexible filament this is not the best solution.
Also the height of the printer gives some issues with the belt tension. To weak and it slips, to high and the stepper motors are protesting. The most optimal tension, will slap the belt during printing( fast movement). This is now reduced by the larger side plate of the carriage. How this affects the durability of the belt, i can only guess. But after a few prints i can't see any wear or tear.

author: Hatsyflatsy

description.text:
See a short demo of the lamp on Youtube: https://youtu.be/Z-aCkDBhwaY

I needed something to remove the smoke when soldering and build this USB powered solder fume fan lamp with an ESP8266 arduino, WS2812b/Neopixels, a fan with an active coal filter and a PIR sensor.

The case is lasercutted in 4 mm plywood.

When there is no movement beneath the lamp the fan turns off after e.g. 60 seconds (can be extended to e.g. 1800 when holding down the fan button) and the LED turns off after 1800 seconds of inactivity. The LED intensity can be dimmed by holding down the LED button.

Parts list:

  • 4 mm plywood for the laser cutted case
  • Ikea Forså lamp ( http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/80146777/ )
  • WS2812b / Neopixel strip (30 LED/m, 12 LED's are used for the lamp. I bought it on Ali Express)
  • Level shifter from 3.3 V to 5 V for the 3.3 V output from the PIR sensor (https://www.adafruit.com/product/757 I bougt it on AliExpress)
  • 1.5 mF capacitor betwen +5 V and ground near the Neopixels, for evening out voltage drops and ripple from the USB power.
  • PIR sensor (https://www.adafruit.com/product/189 I bought it on AliExpress)
  • Fan (80 mm, 12 V. It was just laying around)
  • Wemos D1 mini (https://www.wemos.cc/product/d1-mini.html)
  • Wemos ProtoBoard (https://www.wemos.cc/product/protoboard.html)
  • Wemos RelayShield for turning the fan on and off (https://www.wemos.cc/product/relay-shield.html)
  • MT3608 DC-DC Step Up Power Module from AliE for the power for the 12 V fan
  • Activated coal filter (adjusted the size with a scissor) (https://www.conrad.de/de/aktivkohlefilter-3teilig-toolcraft-79-7201-588546.html i bought it on AliE)
  • two push buttons, connecting the pins from the ESP8266 to ground.
  • USB cable
  • A few strips, pig tail wires, bolt and nuts etc.

The case is glued together with normal wood glue and the PIR sensor and the WS2812b Neopixel strips are glued against the case with cyanoacrylate. The DC-DC converter is fixed with a cable tie. The Wemos D1 mini is fixed with a small bolt through a drilled hole in the ProtoBoard. The capacitor and the level shifter is glued with a hot glue gun. Be aware that there is very little room for the boards and the wires. If I were to build it again I would make some more room. Also the "stack" of the Wemos ProtoBoard, D1 mini and RelayShield is higher than the fan + activated coal filter, so it sticks out of the top, which I think is fine. All the parts do not need to be hidden away for the eye to see :-)

The software is available at:
https://github.com/sman-dk/arduino/tree/master/solder_fume_lamp
Since the ESP8266/Wemos D1 mini has wifi capability future improvements of the software will of course be to make it controllable via wifi :)

comments.text: Not being negative here, but simply a realist with a back ground in robotic engineering and chemistry. This generator would work, but not with using ABS or PLA, or most any 3D printing filament. You see unless this stays at a very low RPM with a very low amperage and voltage, it would produce more than enough heat to destabilize the plastic binder in most all filaments. Theres a big difference between being negative and being safe. Now if you were to redesign this using aluminum, or a metal, or even high temp polymer, it'd work. Alternately you would have to severely cripple its RPM/ Voltage & amperage input/output.
comments.author: Nelujones

comments.text: This is just a project and it's not even a 100% finish. This model really works and I do not have to redesign anything because a LATHE or a CNC machine with 4-5 milling axes could reproduce this project in aluminum or metal perfectly. nowbody says that has to be plastic. A car project/design/manufacturing start from clay so....When I will finish I will make it in aluminum.
comments.author: Iktomi

comments.text: Dude why are you getting so offended? I'm just stating it isn't safe to use of the printer. I'm giving you constructive criticism. I even stated "This generator would work, but not with using ABS or PLA, or most any 3D printing filament." I never said "This is a piece of crap that won't work." I could understand you being upset if I was simply downing it, but I haven't, and won't. Trust me I know how it feels to be really proud of a design, and then to have someone point out flaws in the prototype. title: Little Sun Solar light replacement body
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Little Sun – Solar powered light

Artist Olafur Eliasson and engineer Frederik Ottesen developed http://littlesun.com Original to bring clean, affordable light to the 1.1 billion people worldwide living without electricity in ‘off-grid’ areas.

I have two of these lamps that my children often use at night to read with. Unfortunately, after a slightly too enthusiastic game, one of the lamps cases got damaged.

The great design of these lamps means its very easy to take apart and looking at the structure, I decided to utilise my 3D modelling skills and recreate the design suitable for 3D printing.

A couple of iterations later and the first fully functional version came off my printer. I reused the electronics, lens and on/off cover. Fitted all to my 3D printable version and now my daughter has a very fetching green Little Sun!

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

All parts can print without supports or raft if your 3D printer has good bed adhesion and cooling, but a raft and supports can help if needed.
A front piece with built on supports has been included in the stl files.

You will need to have the electronics and parts from an Little Sun original.
All parts will unclip and clip/fit onto the 3D printed body.
The inner base plate will need to be test fitted to check screws and all parts fit correctly, once happy with parts fit glue the inner plate to the top.

author: MrKindergarten

description.text:
I saw one of these years ago made in wood.
The handle follows an elliptical path whilst the blocks move in linear slots.
Stangely comforting to use.

• Print 2 blocks, 1 bar, one handle and base.

  • Tidy up the holes in the bar.

  • Insert one block into each slot.

  • Use washers and self tappers to attach the bar to the blocks.

  • Attach the handle, again with self tapper and washer.
    • Hint. Don't overtoghten the screws, there should be free movement of the parts.

title: Delta U Joints Large and small

description.text:
I have designed two sizes of the same style Delta U-Joint. I have yet to print and test these but all measurements are taken to accommodate either a 623zz bearing and 7mm rod, or a 624zz bearing and 5mm rod. I was looking to make a simple cost effective yet sooth running U Joint where you could purchase some carbon fiber arrows cheaply found online and convert those into push rods for your delta 3d printer.

The larger U-Joint also uses 8-32 screws and nuts while the small U-Joint uses M3 hardware.

As soon as I get a chance I will print and post pic's of the U-Joints with bearings and nuts installed

comments.text: Damnnn
comments.author: max08

description.text:
My uncle has regular seizures, during which time his mobility is significantly impaired.  Since he loses control of his legs, it makes it very difficult for my aunt to move him around when he is using his walker.
She asked me if it was possible to add footrests from a common wheelchair to the walker.  This would allow him to get his feet off of the ground, and then she can push him.  The advantage is that getting around becomes easier because the walker is used this way 90% of the time, so she only needs to fall back on the footrest every now and then.  The disadvantage is that this voids any warranty on the walker.
I initially thought about sandblasting the paint, machining brackets, and then welding them on.  The obvious issue here is the high cost of iteration, both in time and money.  Plastic isn't exactly cheap, either, but printing the various revisions was still cheaper, and much, much faster.  I came up with a design that was fairly small, requires few external components, and doesn't require any modification to the walker.  They can be removed pretty easily.

You'll want to get the following parts: (4) M6x30 SS dowels, McMaster part #91585A169
(4) M8x50 flathead socket cap screws (I used McMaster part #92925A164)
(4) M8 jam nuts (I found some at home) Print one of each part on your printer's solid setting. Press the dowels into the hole in each part so that 12-15mm or so protrudes from the top. This will prevent the footrest from falling off during normal use. Remove both front wheels of the walker, and the side support beams. Slide the "top" pieces on first, so that the dowels are on the outside of the walker. Now replace the support beam. Finally, add the "lower" pieces. Reattach the front wheels. At this point, you just have to play with the spacing so the footrest can rest on both upper surfaces of the parts. This is my first accessibility-themed part, but I am very happy with the way it came out, and it is making my aunt's and uncle's lives much better!

comments.text: I love the idea - but want to add a caution, that may not apply to you personally.  If the two people using this are both older then it can be a hazard to push someone in a walker.  the wheels are not meant to do that and can easily get tripped up by things that won't bother a wheelchair.  So if it is a must, by all means do what you need to do. But i would recommend that you go with a wheelchair whenever possible.

description.text:
Alright guys, Ive added a Token Case Lid to the excellent holder that was already on here. I have included the token holder as well as the lid. I really needed this for tournaments as the token holder was amazing but their wasn't an option for a template holder and I hate having my templates thrown all over. The lid has space for all your maneuver templates and 5 range ruler sized pieces on the back row. This lid isn't completely snug fitting but is within 1-2mm and works well. Just don't expect it to be a tight fit box. This is my first time putting anything up on Thingverse so I apologize if their are any issues.

Their are two lids included, the flat generic one and then a more decorative one. If you need it to say something else let me know and Ill try to check my messages and add text and send you the file.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57281

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=57281

I wanted to use my Festool OF1010 router and LR32 rail to drip shelf pins and other LR32 system holes. The Festool LR32 router adapter was a bit out of my budget so I created this to work with the OF1010 router and be able to use the index slots.
I added a bolt with nuts and a spring to index the router to the holes. This fits between the router and the router rail guide.
I included a raid guide spacer to set back the holes either 32 or 48 mm from the edge of the board. These just use standard knurled bolts I got from Lowes or Home Depot

comments.text: I don't have a video of it at this time. It works very similarly to the Festool LR32 system, with the change of lifting the bolt instead of a lever

description.text:
EDIT (10/24/2016 2:10) To add a little bit more personality to the dock, I have uploaded four files that can be printed in different colors to create the Google "G" logo. These can be glued into the existing "G" imprint.

EDIT (10/22/2016 3:10) Speakers alignment fixed! Sorry for the issue!

This dock is built for the new Google Pixel XL phone. The dock is specially designed to accompany features of the Pixel XL. Most importantly, it allows the device to be charged by including a hole for a USB Type-C charging cable. The dock also includes carefully placed and curved holes to not only allow sound to escape the bottom of the phone, but also to slightly amplify it. It also allows use of the microphone. This is great for use of the Google Assistant. The dock also sits low enough that the fingerprint scanner on the back is accessible, as are the volume and power buttons. Finally, the dock has a slightly raised wall to prevent the phone from falling out during normal use.

 Important Note: Dock fits Google Pixel XL phone with most normal cases, but not with ones that are very thick. To allow use of thicker cases, the slightly-raised front wall can be removed!

Let me know if you make one! It will mean a lot!

This is a universal spool holder that fits any size spools and has it lay on its side which makes it easy to place and swap rolls of filament.

Standard Skateboard Bearings were used, here is a link to the ones I had lying around.

comments.text:
Hello,
Thanks for sharing. Your design is simply and beautiful !
Let me contribute and share my idea, inspired by a cover that I use for one of my photographic lens.
I suck at 3D design (for the moment) so I did a plane 2D plan, hope you get the idea. One has to push the green piston to make yellow ones retreat and let the spooler in. Once released the spool should be hold in place by the yellow pistons that are pushed by the red springs. The head of the yellow pistons can be modified to be guided to get "inside" the blue cylinder (that is attached to the spinning part) all depends on the diameter of the blue cylinder. All consist in choosing right spring tensions. After installation of the springs,yellow and green piston, a cover can be printed and some screws can hold it in place. I think, it can be fit on the top on any printer (especially printers that "travel" to one place to another) to hold the spooler, without the need of any pieces to install (external spooler holders or so).
What do you think ? Hope I ignite some ideas !
Thanks again for sharing and the time.

Or a design could be made to use the syringe system by adding 2 parts on each side of the green "button" (hold the parts with 2 fingers) and push the green part with the thumb.
I'm currently learning Blender and DesignSpark Mechanical, hope to come with a make some day :)

title: Pocket-Tactics: Core Set 3 (Fourth Edition)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CORE SET 3: The Trans-Universal Dominion against the Zero Syndicate

Welcome to the Fourth Edition of Pocket-Tactics, the modular, 3d-printable strategy board game that goes wherever you do!

This new edition represents years of streamlining, and we're excited to be ready to present this to you. For our third release, we've gone with a new take on the old Dominion set. This time, the interdimensional police force has its hands full in an asymmetrical battle with the nefarious Zero Syndicate for control of a bustling mega-city. Stay tuned for more sets and pieces, as well as updated rules for all of the previous edition's pieces. (DESIGNER'S NOTE-- A few of these pieces were delicate prints when split, though this could be due to printer issues, so a couple of files may change slightly in the near future, but if it works fine for you, then go for it..--)

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

-------------------------------------------------RULES-------------------------------------------------------
For a standard core set, you'll want to print the following:
Dominion Enforcer x1, Dominion Peacekeeper x1, Dominion Arcanist x1, Dominion ExoKnight x1, Undercity Informant x1, Intergalactic Rogue x1, Syndicate Gangster x1, Syndicate Plugger x1, Femme Fatale x1, Syndicate Overboss x1, Grid tiles x9, Water tiles x3, Complex x3

In addition, each player will need six dice (three red, and three blue).

Inverted-color images of the rules cards are available here, here. and here if you want something a little less ink-intensive.

SETTING UP

To begin, each player builds a force by selecting a number of units that total 50 points or less. For a larger game, you and your opponent could agree on a higher point total.

Next, each player chooses 6 tiles and all of the tiles are dropped into a bag and shuffled. Then, players agree (randomly, if you choose) on a “central feature” tile and then each choose a feature for themselves. (features are the 3-dimensional tiles such as Forest, Highlands, Villages, et cetera). Draw a single tile from the bag and place the central feature into that tile. Rolling off to see who goes first, players take turns drawing tiles from the bag and placing them adjacent to one another in whatever configuration they wish. Once all of the tiles have been placed, each player (in turn order decided by the roll-off) places their chosen feature so that it is both as many tiles away from the center and from one another as possible.

Once the map has been generated, players place up to three units of their choice (as many as they can fit) either in or adjacent to their chosen feature using the rolled-off turn order. You may only ever have a single unit occupy a tile or feature. Once this is finished, game play begins starting with the last player to place their units.

PLAYING THE GAME

Each turn, a player may either move one of their units, use one of their units to assault an enemy unit, or deploy a new unit onto the map.

MOVING: When activating a unit to move, they may do so into any unoccupied tile adjacent to them. If an allied unit is in an adjacent tile, the moving unit may “hop” over that unit to get to an open tile adjacent to their ally. A unit may only hop a single ally per move. Some features (Forests, Highlands, Villages, et cetera) have special movement considerations that will be listed on their rules card. Spaces that do not contain a tile may not be moved into.

SWIFT UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move.

FLYING UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move and may hop over enemy units as though they were allies when doing so.

ASSAULTS: When activating a unit to assault an adjacent enemy, each player tests their units Offense (OFF) by rolling their red dice and defense (DEF) by rolling their blue dice. A unit will have between zero and three of each kind of dice as shown on their rules cards. The assault occurs in three phases:

Roll Phase- All dice are rolled simultaneously.

Bump Phase- Some units have “bumps,” a numeric value with a + listed under either their OFF or DEF dice. Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player may take turns using a single bump. Each bump may adjust a single die result (either OFF or DEF) up by its value (though a single die may not go higher than 6). Some units may have multiple bump values listed under their dice or granted by special abilities or terrain effects.

Re-Roll Phase- Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player takes turns using any re-rolls they are afforded, either by special abilities or terrain/unit placement. Each re-roll allows the player to re-roll one of their die results (OFF or DEF). A unit that has adjacent allies is benefiting from “support” and gains one re-roll per ally. A unit also gains a single re-roll when occupying their “favored terrain” (a terrain tile or feature that is shown on their rules card).

Tally Phase- Each player checks their OFF results and checks them against the opponent's DEF results. Starting with the highest OFF die, compare it to the highest enemy DEF die. If the results are a tie, move on to the next highest. If a single OFF die can't be matched by an equal or greater value from the enemy's DEF, that enemy is “defeated” and is removed from the map and placed in the victorious player's captures (a space to the side of the map on that player's side). If the OFF cannot beat the enemy DEF values, that unit is safe. Note that, because all dice are rolled at once, it is possible for both units to defeat one another simultaneously.

RANGED ATTACKS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may make assaults against units that are an extra number of tiles away equal to the numeric value listed to the side. Count through the closest route to get to the target and apply any effects from intervening features before making a ranged assault. Enemy units block line of sight (except when a Flying unit is targeted or is making the assault) and empty spaces always block line of sight. If a unit being assaulted is not capable of meeting the range requirements to the attacker, they may not roll their OFF dice for that assault.

DEPLOYMENT: In place of activating one of your units already on the map, you may choose a unit from your reserves (any of the units you didn't put on the map at the start of the game that haven't been captured by enemies) and place them adjacent to any feature on the map that you control (provided the space is unoccupied). If no such tile exists, you may not deploy a unit until one opens up.

Any player may, in place of performing a regular move action, move a piece into an occupied feature tile to return that unit to reserves. Similarly, a unit that is occupying a feature may move into that feature to return to reserves, though you then cede control of the feature by doing so.

TYPES

Listed directly beneath a unit's name are a number of “types” (Human, Elf, Robot, et cetera). These types have no effect on their own, though are referenced by certain abilities and terrain effects that may either be beneficial or detrimental to the unit.

HAZARDS

Some terrain tiles and features contain hazards. These are special effects that occur when a unit is moved into that tile. Units that are deployed into a tile with hazard effects ignore them, as do units that have that tile type as their favored terrain.

WATER: A unit moving into a Water tile must succeed at a DV 5 DEF test or be defeated immediately after doing so.

If a feature is placed in a terrain tile, the tile counts as that feature rather than the terrain type, and therefore negates any hazard effects native to the terrain type.

VICTORY CONDITIONS

A player achieves victory as soon as their opponent (or opponents) cannot activate or deploy any units. Alternately, victory is secured the moment any single player controls all features on the map.

one major reason being the dominion only has 4 characters meanwhile the syndicate has 6 characters. me and friend were probably playing it wrong so got a few questions and or suggestions.
it should be stated more or less like this
"each turn a player can activate a unit to either, (i added activated here because it wasnt stated as such after which confused us especially when we started reading the abilities and was wondering what an activation was when it states here move,assault or deploy outta nowhere)
-move
-assault (melee or ranged)
-or deploy
think it would be easier in dot form then have the headings for those with any sub headings related to special rules and/or abilities which i have a question coming up.

with assault the whole mentioning of the starting player initiating the assault and taking turns to bump, reroll and tally shouldnt has both players have rolled the dice and may reroll simultaneous for one instance (unless theres no adjacent friendlys but for this case lets say both players can rerol) this gets a tad confusing same issue with the mentioning of activation.
with bumping says cant go more than 6 so what about if you roll a 5 and your bump +2 that would make it 7 so do you either count it as a 6,not able to bump that die roll of 5 but bump the secondary die for some reason or dont bump at all.
also after the assault phase either melee or shooting if the fight ends in a tie nothing happens, the units stay in the same spot and ends turn right there and then right?
units with range capability can they fight in melee/adjacent assault
with walking on water you have to roll the amount of defense dice depending on character and get a 5+ on at least one die, can bumps, featres and abilities apply here or no.
with the arcanist it says if the attacking unit "has" arcane mage/psion type on the map? or in reserves? or in graveyard/captured

comments.text: One question about the ExoKnight: It's ability allows me to deploy a unit adjacent, and then make two activations. To what unit do these activations apply? Can one of these activations be used to deploy yet another unit and get another two activations?
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Well, first off it doesn't let you deploy your own unit, you're returning a unit you captured into an adjacent tile (so one of your enemy's pieces) but then look at it like taking two extra turns. You get two "Activations." You could use them each to deploy a piece, move a piece, or assault with a piece, and you could use them both on the same unit if you like.
comments.author: Codeflare

comments.text: Oh! Okay, so I get to trade giving an opponent's piece back to them for two activations. That makes WAAAAY more sense. Which means if I kept using activations to get more activations, I would also have an exoknight completely overrun with enemies once the turn is over.
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Haha, yeah. It's a great option to have, but you'll want to use it sparingly/tactically.
comments.author: Codeflare

comments.text: Oh! But yes, absolutely: If you can return multiple enemies, you can keep taking bonus turns. You've gotta have space to do that, of course, but if you can, go for it. I'm just now reading that correctly, haha.

comments.text: This could lead to an annoying "endless turn" in which Exoknight returns easily-beaten enemy to spot adjacent to itself and the rest of his Dominion buddies, uses one bonus activation to mercilessly remove the enemy and the second to return that same enemy to play. Rinse, repeat.

author: dutchmogul

title: bubba Flo water bottle lock clasp / clip

description.text:
Replacement lock clip / clasp for the bubba brand Flo water bottle. Their website is www.bubbabrands.com. This clasp acts as a backup to the lock that holds the lid closed. In the US you can buy a replacement lid for $5. I'm living overseas, so this was kind of like an astronaut on Mars designing and printing a needed replacement part. Never mind the fact that I could have just visited the local supermarket and bought a new bottle of another brand. This was a fun challenge for me and extended the useful life of the bottle to the delight of my teen who uses it daily.

I sketched this clip using Autodesk Fusion 360. It was my first CAD project in many years and I was impressed with the powerful software that is now available to the hobbyist for free. Amazingly the clasp fit perfectly first print and the PLA held up for six months going through the dishwasher five times a week! I sliced it with Simplify3D using medium PLA settings (0.2 mm layer thickness, 100% infill), and printed on a Flash Forge Creative Pro printer. I just finished reprinting in ABS. The ABS was warping and the pegs were really bad until I turned the temperature down, then I got a usable print but it was not as precise as the PLA. I need to adjust my temp settings more and maybe add custom supports under the pegs. For some reason the monogram on the sketch did not show up on the .stl file. Any ideas why?

comments.text: this looks pretty good ... why the weight difference between the black and white?  are those weights all in? with the 260mah? oh and one more question :)  do you think this frame could be printed with pla or abs?
comments.author: ulightme

comments.text: The white is in ABS & the black is in Onix (Nylon reinforced with short Carbon Fibers) the same type of battery is always used (Nanotech 260 35C) there can be up to one gram difference from batterie to batterie, but the ABS frame is slightly heavier than the Onix one & it is more fragile. The blue drone as seen on the video is the most used and probably went through more than 1000 crashes & only shows minimal delaminations on the front bumpers, the white one started to breake after 10 crashes. the roll cage is a bit fragile in ABS & would benefit being reinforced. PLA is more brittle than ABS therefore I would not advise using it for drones, except if you plan not to crash.

title: Parametric Foot (based on Marshall cabinet feet design)

description.text:
This is a generic project foot design based on the feet used on Marshall cabinets. It is fully parametric, so the size and the holes can be adjusted. The round edge will automatically adjust to the params.  
I'd suggest to print it with extra shell and bottom layers and good infill if you want to put some weight on it. I can imagine it would also work quite well with flexi PLA or ABS for shock absorbtion.
I also added an .stl file for folks who don't use OpenScad. It has the exact size of my Marshall cabinet feet, but I don't know if all series have the same size feet.

description.text:
I wanted to print some feet to raise my Play up a bit to allow wires to go underneath. I've seen designs that use flexible filament, but I don't have any so I designed these to utilize small bouncy balls (~1" / 25mm diameter) from the dollar store and bolts/nuts to attach to the printer. I have two files, one designed for a 6mm bolt and one designed for a 1/4-20 bolt.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pPyl5HwsVfk

UPDATE: I have since upgraded to the extended Y heated bed. The extra mass of the extended bed caused the printer to rock considerably more with the soft bouncy balls I used. If I could find some that were firmer, it may work better, but for the time being, I have removed these and am using the original rubber pad feet.

12 Volt Mini Lantern

I was trying to reimagine a mini lantern within the confines of todays LED panels and batteries, and developed this Pocket Lantern. It is a little larger than a bar of soap, uses 3-18650 cells to produce 12V, with a 280ma approximately 300 lumen light. It is as bright as any of my D-cell lanterns, and you can put it comfortably in your pocket. The swing-out feet give added stability. Run time for 2000ma batteries is around 8 hours.

The light panel and switch are both recessed so they don't catch in your pocket or get switched accidentally. For overhead use (camping, tenting) suspend by the feet. The switch is offset to allow adding a battery management system later, if desired. Use 4mm o-ring for weather tightness. This groove also fits screen door screen spline, available at most hardware stores.

The ight panel used is 40x60mm, available on Amazon, described as "EverBrightt 6-Pack Cool White 1210 48SMD Led Panel Dome Light Bulbs" for $16.99. The round push-button switch is available on Amazon described as "10 Pcs Latching Action SPST Round Red Push Button Switch AC 125V 3A" for $3.99. Any similar products will work as well.

Shells for the front are included both for the inset 40x60mm panel, and an un-indented 5mm thick shell you can indent yourself. The box is secured by 3mm printing filament on both sides.

Printing:
I printed this on a Taz-6 with PLA, flat side down. Support is only needed for the panel indent on the lid. I printed 5 top layers, 3 side and bottom layers, 30% infill. It is a good solid box.

title: 3 inch diameter High Power Rocket Avionics Bay

description.text:
This is an avionics bay for a 3 inch minimum diameter rocket. Due to space limitations in a 3 inch rocket the traditional sled design does not give enough room for two altimeters and batteries along with connectors for ejection charges. The bay is set up for a Featherweight Raven and PerfectFlite Stratologger, both running off 9V batteries, which are contained in the battery compartment. Compartments and altimeters are mounted with brass threaded inserts from McMaster-Carr.

The AV bay is assembled using three 10-24 allthreads with thread connectors at each end. Hex head screws (large enough to seal against ejection charge blowthrough) are used to attach the bulkhead to the AV bay internals with ejection connectors. The bulkhead also includes a 3D printed block for some typical phoenix connectors to serve as terminal blocks to save space from the normal bulky screw-down connectors.

This bay flew on my rocket (Sixieme) at BALLS 2016 with no damage through a 19G launch to 23,000 feet and recovery. Maximum speed was 1.8 mach.

Also included is a drill guide for the bulkhead for bay and ejection block alignment.

Insertion into the carbon fiber coupler tube is using guides on an inner ring that retains nuts for outside screws to attach body tubes to AV bay.

Flashforge Creator Pro

comments.text: I printed up all these parts and plan to use it in a min dia 3 inch rocket. Question I have is do you have a list of the McMaster Carr items you ordered to work with it? I believe I saw this fly at Balls 2016. I was there and flew my 11.5" V2 and 6" Black Brant on research N's
comments.author: Gattack

comments.text: Yes, I did fly this at BALLS, but since the main came out at apogee I spent a bunch of time tracking it down (7.5 miles downwind in the hills) so didn't see many other flights.  The airfoil fin design worked great.
comments.author: Gattack

comments.text: Thanks, this is just what I was looking for. I just placed an order with McMaster Carr. I saw the other nosecone mount and plan on printing that as well. I use Multitronics Kate on larger rockets and EggFinder on smaller rockets and this looks like it would work well with the EggFinder. I have a bunch of the Shurter style switches, that it looked like you used, as I got a good deal on them, several years ago. Thanks for sharing and your help :-)
comments.author: randysteck

comments.text: One thing to note when printing the nosecone mount is that you should print it sideways on the print bed using supports as necessary.  I printed it standing on end but found that the stress of launch and chute deployment broke the print along the radial extrusion lines.  When printed on the side, the extrusion lines run longitudinally and are much stronger and don't break during flight.
comments.author: Gattack

title: Kossel Pro/mini Delta E3D V6 End Effector Version 5

description.text:
Also Fits Kossel Mini

This is another attempt at making an end effector for the kossel pro and e3d v6 hotend. It is a direct replacement for the stock end effector. Arm spacing and radius are the same as stock. My previous few have cooled off the heater block too fast and this one does not.

Another goal of this design was to limit the interference between the fans and the arms, so i've put the fans in the center and reduced the part cooling fans from 3 to 2. A new duct system puts the air flow closer to the nozzle, which will hopefully improve PLA prints greatly. It mounts to the bottom with 3 #4 screws.

Other minor improvements include a cable tie mount for clean cable routing and a single bolt hot end clamp to reduce the bulk and number of parts needed. Single layer tabs aid in bed adhesion for small surface area sections.

see the older version 3: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1765913

Parts List:
E3d V6 Hotend
3x 30x30x10mm fans 24V or 12V depending on your printer
6x #4 5/8" thread rolling screws for plastic (amazon)
3x #4 3/8" thread rolling screws for plastic (amazon)
3x 5x37mm internally threaded tube (comes stock with the kossel pro)
1x M3x4mmx5mm Female Threaded Brass Knurled Insert Embedded Nut (amazon)
1x M3 10 or 12mm bolt (you should have a few laying around)

UPDATE (I know its been less than a day)
New files. The fan duct screws wouldn't let the hotend to fit all the way in. I moved the screws to the outside and made the fan duct wrap 230 degrees around instead of just two opposing sides. Screws that secure the part cooling fans now have more material to thread into. I also added a parts list.

UPDATE 12/7/16
I got this thing dialed in. The fan duct was expanded outward for more air flow. The inside wall is further away from the heater block and has thicker walls supported by ribs to greatly reduce deformation with heat. The ribs also direct airflow to the nozzle. Shorter 3/8" #4 screws are used to mount the fan duct for a cleaner look. A cable tie mount was added in the back for clean cable management. The tolerance for the hot end clamp was reduced from .4mm to .2mm for a tighter fit.

print_settings.Notes:: I noticed that the hall sensors had those nice red LED-s, which is why I made housing pretty thin so they could glow through the plastic. That makes your printer 5% cooler. :D

description.text:
For time beings I have settled with mechanical endstops but recently I started to doubt their accuracy and I did not like the way how carriers are crushing to them.

To fix this issue I decided to use hall sensors which should be a more precise and did not need any physical contact between carriage and endstop switch.

I got my Hall sensors from Aliexpress for about 3€. Note that you will need magnets to trigger Hall sensors (I had some 12mm disc magnets laying around).

Due to the Hall endstops homing my Delta is pretty silent compared to the mechanical switches. Accuracy seems to be also spot on.

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I noticed that the hall sensors had those nice red LED-s, which is why I made housing pretty thin so they could glow through the plastic. That makes your printer 5% cooler. :D

Putting everything together

Print out 3x Hall sensor housings and magnet holders (if you decide to use 12mm disc magnets).

Modifiy your hall sensor's sensor (this black thingy that detects magnetic field) so it would be at 90 degree angle from electronics board.

Place hall sensor to its housing and use regular M4 screw to mount it to the printer. I managed to use same bolts that kept the mechanical endstops in place.

Note: Hall sensor uses three wire setup (5V, GND, signal). If you have used passive endstops (only two wires - GND, signal) then you will need to provide additional 5V wire also.

Put magnets to the magnet holder and use superglue to fix the holder to the carriages.

For better or worse, we live in a throw-away society. Here's hoping that we can re-purpose at least a handful of paper towel tubes that would otherwise be discarded.

Simply cut the paper towel tube into 3 close-to-equal pieces, staple both ends together and then slip into this base for a nice solid DIY pen holder... and maybe a great project for the kids.

It'll probably work with toilet paper roll tubes as well so long as they are 42.4mm (plus or minus a millimeter) in diameter.

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

title: Streamlight Super Tac X Lens Cap

description.text: This is a lens cap for a Streamlight Super Tac X flashlight. It's designed to be printed with a FLEXIBLE filament so it's got a snug fit. This part will probably be too small if you print it with a standard filament.

author: lb7000
